title: 111_hr184
content: The "Clean Vehicles for Cleaner Air Act of 2009" may be cited as the short title. It introduces a clean-fuel credit for businesses in nonattainment areas under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Clean Vehicles for Cleaner Air Act of 2009 introduces a clean-fuel credit for eligible businesses under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit includes the clean-fuel property credit and the clean-burning fuel use credit. The clean-fuel property credit consists of qualified vehicle property costs and qualified refueling property costs. Qualified vehicle property costs refer to expenses for qualified clean-fuel vehicle property placed in service during the taxable year. The Clean Vehicles for Cleaner Air Act of 2009 introduces a clean-fuel credit for eligible businesses under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit includes the clean-fuel property credit for qualified vehicle property costs placed in service during the taxable year in a nonattainment area. There are limitations on the amount that can be taken into account based on the type of motor vehicle. The Clean Vehicles for Cleaner Air Act of 2009 offers a clean-fuel credit for businesses under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. This credit applies to qualified vehicle property costs for vehicles over 26,000 pounds or buses with a seating capacity of at least 20 adults. Qualified clean-fuel vehicle property excludes vehicles using non-clean-burning fuels. Qualified refueling property costs are also defined for this purpose. The term 'qualified refueling property costs' refers to amounts paid for clean-fuel vehicle refueling property placed in service by an eligible business in a nonattainment area during the taxable year. There is a limitation on the aggregate cost that can be taken into account, which is the lesser of $150,000 or the cost of the property. The cost of qualified refueling property is reduced by the aggregate amount previously taken into account for all preceding taxable years and under section 179A(a)(1)(B) by the taxpayer. The clean-burning fuel use credit is 50 cents for each gasoline gallon equivalent of clean-burning fuel used by an eligible business to propel qualified clean-fuel vehicle property. The term 'clean-burning fuel' is defined accordingly. The term 'clean-burning fuel' includes compressed natural gas and biodiesel, with a gasoline gallon equivalent defined as the amount of fuel with a Btu content of 114,000. An eligible business is defined as a qualified business entity or proprietorship in a nonattainment area. The term 'nonattainment area' is defined by the Clean Air Act. No double benefits are allowed for expenses eligible for other deductions or credits. The Secretary can recapture credits for property not used primarily in a nonattainment area. The Clean Air Act defines 'nonattainment area'. No double benefits for expenses eligible for other deductions or credits. Credits for property not used primarily in a nonattainment area can be recaptured. Amendments made to sections 38 and 280C of the tax code regarding clean-fuel credit. The tax code is amended to allow for the clean fuels credit under section 45R to be used against regular and minimum tax, as well as for deduction of certain unused business credits. The tax code is amended to allow for the clean fuels credit under section 45R to be used against regular and minimum tax, as well as for deduction of certain unused business credits. Conforming Amendment: The table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of such Code is amended by inserting after the item relating to section 45Q the following new item. The tax code is amended to allow for the clean-fuel credit for businesses in nonattainment areas. Effective after December 31, 2008. Additionally, a credit for hybrid vehicles in nonattainment areas is introduced. The tax code is amended to provide a 200% credit for new qualified hybrid motor vehicles used by eligible businesses in nonattainment areas, in place of the credit allowed under subsection (a)(3). The tax code is amended to provide a 200% credit for new qualified hybrid motor vehicles used by eligible businesses in nonattainment areas. The Secretary will recapture the benefit if the property's use is not in a nonattainment area, and the phaseout does not apply. Effective date is after December 31, 2008.
